hero.headline: How to Handle YouTube Copyright Claims
hero.subheadline: Understand, dispute, and avoid copyright issues on YouTube.

sections.content: Copyright claims are part of YouTube life—Content ID automatically scans uploads against a database of protected content. Most claims aren't channel-threatening, but they affect monetization and can escalate. Understanding the system helps you respond appropriately and avoid issues in the first place.

content.title: Content ID Claim
content.description: Automated detection. Usually affects monetization only.

content.title: Monetization Claim
content.description: Revenue goes to claimant. Video stays up.

sections.title: Best Practices
content: Use YouTube's copyright check before publishing
Fair use is complex—not automatic protection

faq.question: What's the difference between claim and strike?
faq.answer: Claim: usually Content ID automated, affects monetization. Strike: manual takedown request, serious penalty, 3 strikes = channel termination. Claims don't become strikes unless you dispute and lose.

faq.question: Can I use copyrighted music if I credit?
faq.answer: No—credit doesn't grant permission. You need actual license. 'No copyright intended' means nothing legally. Use licensed music from Epidemic Sound, Artlist, or YouTube Audio Library.

faq.question: Is fair use automatic protection?
faq.answer: No—fair use is a legal defense, not automatic right. It's complex (purpose, amount, effect on market). Commentary/criticism helps, but not guaranteed. Many disputes over fair use fail.

faq.question: How long do claims last?
faq.answer: Claims can be permanent unless disputed/released. Some claimants release after period. You can trim claimed content to remove. Video stays up with monetization claim—just revenue affected.
